thread.title_full: Starbucks: Cooling Down

posts.title: Starbucks: Cooling Down
posts.text:
Send Message Summary 
Commodities have been in flux over the past few months and it has hit Starbucks' margins pretty hard. 
With its input costs rising and considering it is a consumer discretionary spending item it is highly likely that the consumer will curtail their spending at “The Third Place”. 
With these troubles ailing the stock I wanted to employ a bearish options strategy in the name to make a profit. Since President Elect Donald Trump has been on the campaign trail urging for retailers to bring Christmas back and outright asking his supporters to boycott Starbucks (NASDAQ: SBUX ) the stock of coffee brewer from Seattle has been dropping. But drop in the stock price can't be all attributed to the boycott calls of Mr. Trump. The company has had some of its own difficulties along the way. Commodities have been in flux over the past few months and it has hit Starbucks' margins pretty hard. Their main commodity is obviously coffee and price of those beans has been skyrocketing of late. There has been a huge drought in Brazil which has not allowed farmers to grow their crops like normal this time of year which has contributed to the spike in prices. This is anticipated to be Brazil's worst coffee harvest for quite some time . Next year's crops are bound to have some trouble producing anything as well if the drought continues. Brazil is the largest producer of coffee beans and following them is Vietnam who has also been experiencing its own coffee crop issues this year. With its input costs rising and considering it is a consumer discretionary spending item it is highly likely that the consumer will curtail their spending at "The Third Place". Coupled with rising input costs the stock itself trades at a fairly rich valuation at 22x next year's earnings estimates. When we take a look at a chart below of the stock relative to the S&P 500 and the Consumer Discretionary ETF (NYSEARCA: XLY ) we see that it has been a relative loser over the past year. Click to enlarge With these troubles ailing the stock I wanted to employ a bearish options strategy in the name to make a profit. What I did was I wrote the November $50 put for $0.73 and used the proceeds to purchase the November $52.50 put for $1.25. In aggregate, the trade cost me $0.52 but it looks like the market is about to turn over again after our brief presidential election rally and I hope to turn it into a profitable trade. The trade was profitable until the company reported earnings and has since found support here at around $54. The stock however is down nearly 13% from its 52-week high while the Dow Jones Industrial keeps making record highs. The earnings growth is still there with next year's earnings estimated to grow roughly 15.3% from 2016 but with November as the expiration date I selected that shouldn't matter. I have until the end of the week for this strategy to play out to my favor so only time will tell. Thanks for reading and I look forward to your comments! Disclaimer: This article is in no way a recommendation to buy or sell any stock mentioned. This article is meant to serve as a journal for myself as to the rationale of why I bought/sold this stock when I look back on it in the future. These are only my personal opinions and you should do your own homework. Only you are responsible for what you trade and happy investing! Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.   it (other than from Seeking Alpha). thread.title: AAA predicting biggest Thanksgiving travel rush in 9 years
thread.title_full: AAA predicting biggest Thanksgiving travel rush in 9 years

posts.author: DAVID KOENIG
posts.title: AAA predicting biggest Thanksgiving travel rush in 9 years
posts.text: Starbucks turns to customers for annual holiday cup designs DALLAS (AP) -- The slowly improving economy could boost travel over the Thanksgiving holiday to levels not seen in nine years. AAA forecasts that 48.7 million Americans will travel, the busiest Thanksgiving period on U.S. roads and skies since 2007, the year before the global financial crisis plunged the U.S. economy into a deep recession. The auto club AAA said Tuesday that it expects 1 million more Americans to venture at least 50 miles from home, a 1.9 percent increase over last year. The forecast was assembled at research firm IHS, which said it considered jobs, household net worth, the stock market, prices for gasoline and airline tickets, and other factors. The researchers did their number crunching in mid-October, about three weeks before the surprising outcome in the presidential election. The AAA forecast predicts that from Wednesday, Nov. 23, through Sunday, Nov. 27, about 43.5 million Americans will take long car trips, 1.9 percent more than last year. AAA expects 3.7 million will travel by air, a 1.6 percent increase. Bus and train trips will grow less than 1 percent, the auto group said. An airline-industry trade group is a bit more bullish. Airlines for America predicts that air travel will rise 2.5 percent over last year's holiday, although the group considers Thanksgiving travel spanning a 12-day period that begins Nov. 18. AIR TRAVEL TIPS Planes are likely to be packed over the holiday, and bad weather or airline computer malfunctions can slow things to a crawl. If the unexpected happens, be ready to react quickly. -Arrive early. At some airports, including Dallas-Fort Worth International and Dallas Love Field, garages and other facilities are under construction, making matters worse. -Pack smart. Don't put anything you really need - medicine, passport, other important papers - in your rollaboard bag; or remember to remove it if the airline orders you to gate-check your bag, which happens when flights are full and bins are overstuffed. -Customer assistance. If your flight is canceled, get in line to talk to an airline customer rep but call the airline too. You might have better luck reaching an overseas number - look up the numbers before your trip.

thread.title: Celebrating Friendsgiving, a Thanksgiving party for friends
thread.title_full: Celebrating Friendsgiving, a Thanksgiving party for friends

posts.author: BETH J. HARPAZ
posts.title: Celebrating Friendsgiving, a Thanksgiving party for friends
posts.text: Starbucks turns to customers for annual holiday cup designs NEW YORK (AP) -- Thanksgiving is traditionally a day for gathering with your family and eating turkey, but there's a twist on the holiday as a purely social gathering, and it's called Friendsgiving. The menu might include anything from beer and cheese fries to cocktails and salmon. But instead of the host slaving away for hours in a hot kitchen, it's more likely to be a party-style potluck. The trend is also turning up in ads, charity promotions, Evites and even on a cruise ship, with Royal Caribbean's Harmony of the Seas ship hosting a Friendsgiving celebration for passengers two weeks before Thanksgiving this year. This fall's premiere issue of The Magnolia Journal, a magazine from HGTV's "Fixer Upper" stars Chip and Joanna Gaines, also featured a story about Friendsgiving. And while Americans have long celebrated Thanksgiving with friends when they couldn't be with family - whether they were living abroad, at college or in the military - Friendsgivings aren't usually replacements for traditional family gatherings. Instead, Friendsgivings are held in addition to the traditional Thursday turkey dinner, specifically scheduled on a different day so as not to conflict with family get-togethers. New Yorker Hannah Redfield says she and her 20-something friends are "really into" Friendsgiving, which they've celebrated since 2014. She calls it "a millennial-driven interpretation of Thanksgiving. This demographic of people isn't as concerned with preparing the traditional Thanksgiving meal but is looking for an excuse to celebrate friendship. In my experience, people aren't necessarily expected to show up with solely mashed potatoes, stuffing, cranberry sauce, etc." Instead, they bring everything from cheese fries to spaghetti squash - "whatever they could muster or afford with entry-level salaries." Nina Foley of Chicago agrees that Friendsgivings offer an opportunity to break traditions: "While a family Thanksgiving would never allow for anything other than traditional canned cranberry, creamed corn casserole or green beans, because it's Friendsgiving, we have the freedom to get creative." One friend in her group went to culinary school and includes ingredients with his gourmet turkey that "none of us ever saw on our plates as kids - figs, preserved oranges, fried sage!" Friendsgivings are also often more like parties than staid sit-down dinners. There are Friendsgiving pajama parties, and themed events with arts and crafts or games. Michelle Platt is hosting her third Friendsgiving this year - a potluck - in Briarcliff Manor, New York, for friends from college who are now in their 40s. "We almost all have kids, so I hire a babysitter to watch them so we can have some adult time," she said. Platt uses the online invitation service Evite for her Friendsgiving and noted that "the first year was slim pickings for invite designs, but now there are a lot to choose from." Evite reports a 29 percent increase this year over last in the number of events that its Friendsgiving designs are being used for, totaling in the thousands. Some Friendsgivings double as fundraisers, with hosts inviting guests to support a good cause. A charity called No Kid Hungry, which focuses on ending childhood hunger by connecting kids to the meals they need, offered a Friendsgiving fundraising option last year and raised $28,000 from some 50 participants. This year, No Kid Hungry has registered 1,400 Friendsgiving fundraisers, raising $78,000 so far. Hosts ask guests for donations or charge for a specific cocktail or treat. Kory Stamper, associate editor for Merriam-Webster, says the term "Friendsgiving" hasn't yet made it into the company's dictionary, but "it's a good candidate for future inclusion." She says Friendsgiving started being used around 2007, with boosts from a 2011 Bailey's Irish Cream ad and also from a "Real Housewives of New Jersey" episode. Branding expert Nancy Friedman said on her blog, Wordworking.com, that Friendsgiving first turned up online in 2004 and was popularized in part by a 2013 Taco Bell promotion. Some people think the term is connected to the TV sitcom "Friends," which was famous for its annual Thanksgiving-with-friends episodes, but Friedman doesn't think the word was ever used on the show, which ended in 2004. Danielle Paleafico, 29, started hosting Friendsgiving five years ago in one of her first apartments after college, and now it's grown into an all-day, drop-in event for 30 to 40 friends at her home in Morristown, New Jersey. "We watch football, I make turkey, all the usual side dishes, homemade pasta and meatballs, dessert, etc.," she said. "Everyone usually brings a dish and a bottle of wine or beer and we all just come together casually, watch the games, catch up and enjoy each other." Timing is important: She picks a date before the real Thanksgiving, and then "we all go our separate ways for the holiday and give thanks with our own families."

thread.title: Florida man arrested after fight about Obama, Clinton breaks out at Starbucks | FOX13

posts.author: Brittney Donovan
posts.title: Florida man arrested after fight about Obama, Clinton breaks out at Starbucks | FOX13
posts.text:
Florida man arrested after fight about Obama, Clinton breaks out at Starbucks 
by: Brittney Donovan, WJAX-TV Jacksonville, Fla. Updated: Nov 15, 2016 - 6:40 AM 
ST. JOHNS COUNTY, Fla. - A Florida man spent the night in jail after a fight about politics broke out at a St. Johns County Starbucks, deputies said. 
William "Bill" Savage, 66, was at a Starbucks in Ponte Vedra Beach with a group of friends on Wednesday when he got into an argument with a man, according to a police report. Related Headlines 
Savage told WJAX that he and his friends have met at the Starbucks to discuss politics and world events every day for nearly 16 years. 
Accused attacker in Ponte Vedra Starbucks fight tells me man called Pres. Obama racial slur so he asked him to leave https://t.co/QWbDyMVJLA pic.twitter.com/7A1ow3BsLO — Brittney Donovan (@brittneydonovan) November 10, 2016 

He said the 42-year-old man he allegedly hit regularly inserted himself in their conversations during the past few months. 
A police report says the fight started after the victim said anyone would be in jail for what Hillary Clinton had done. 
Savage told WJAX that the victim began using racial slurs about President Barack Obama, saying he and Clinton should be in jail. 
Savage told the man to get out of the "family establishment" if he was going to use foul language. 
The police report says Savage then asked him to step outside. 
The victim told deputies once they stepped outside, Savage insulted him and stepped toward him. 
>> Read more Floridoh! stories 
He says he never hit the alleged victim, only used his hand to block man's cowboy hat from hitting his face — Brittney Donovan (@brittneydonovan) November 10, 2016 

The victim told deputies Savage hit him in the left eye, which knocked off his cowboy hat, after he told Savage he had an eye booger. 
The victim said he did not hit Savage back. 
When deputies got to the Starbucks, Savage told them he asked the victim to step outside. 
He told deputies he hit the victim's hat after the man started getting into his personal space and made a move toward him. 
Savage told WJAX that he used his hand to block the man's hat from hitting his face when the man got close to him. 
He said he never laid a hand on the victim. 
Deputies said they took photos of the victim's left eye, which was slightly swollen and red. 
A witness also told deputies she saw Savage hit the victim. 
Savage was arrested for simple battery and was taken to jail. 
>> Read more trending stories

posts.title: Tata Global Beverages ousts Cyrus Mistry as chairman | Reuters
posts.text:
By Aditi Shah | MUMBAI MUMBAI The board of Tata Global Beverages, which co-owns and runs Starbucks coffee stores across India, has replaced Cyrus Mistry as its chairman, the first Tata group company to depose him since his removal last month from the helm of parent holding company Tata Sons.Mistry said in a statement the manner in which he was replaced as chairman of Global Beverages was "inaccurate and illegal," intensifying the high-profile power struggle at the Tata group.In a boardroom coup last month Mistry was removed as chairman of Tata Sons, the holding company for the $100 billion steel-to-software Tata empire in which Mistry's family hold a minority stake. Patriarch Ratan Tata is now back in charge as a bitter public row ensues.Despite being removed as chairman of Tata Sons, and now Tata Global Beverages, Mistry still remains chairman of some of the group's major companies like Tata Motors and Tata Steel, where Tata Sons does not have majority ownership. Tata Sons has called shareholder meetings at these companies to get Mistry ousted from those boards.

The post Tata Global Beverages ousts Cyrus Mistry as chairman
| Reuters appeared first on Firstpost.

posts.author: newsfeedback@fool.com (Jeremy Bowman)
posts.title: This Is Starbucks' Plan to Get Even More of Your Coffee Dollars
posts.text:
More than a decade ago, Starbucks' (NASDAQ: SBUX) ubiquity was often the butt of jokes. The Onion wrote that a Starbucks had opened in the bathroom of an existing Starbucks, and comedian Lewis Black said he had seen the end of the world -- a Starbucks across the street from another Starbucks.
Though it seems that the leading coffee chain long ago reached cultural saturation, it keeps finding new ways to grow. The company's taking over China, where CEO Howard Schultz said he expects there to one day be more stores than in the U.S. It's grown profits through its channel development segment, which includes consumer products such as K-cups and bagged coffee, and it continues to find new ways to expand its footprint even in its home market. Its partnerships with Target (NYSE: TGT) , for example, now has 1,300 Starbucks cafes inside its stores. The company is also licensing its brand in places like college campuses and expanding to new neighborhoods that it might have avoided earlier in its history.

Continue reading

thread.title: Old Glory Relay Flag Crosses the Finish Line with a Starbucks Assist
thread.title_full: Old Glory Relay Flag Crosses the Finish Line with a Starbucks Assist

posts.title: Old Glory Relay Flag Crosses the Finish Line with a Starbucks Assist
posts.text:
Instagram Downloads 
About 4,200 miles after the first of 62 teams departed from Seattle’s Space Needle, the Old Glory Relay ended on Veterans Day in Tampa, Florida. 
Teams of 800 runners, walkers and cyclists carried an American flag from the Northwest to the Southeast in an effort to raise awareness of veterans service organizations and their work supporting veterans. The route started in Washington state on September 11, heading south through Southern California before turning east and continuing through the Southwest and the Gulf Coast, ending in Tampa on November 11. 
Team Red, White & Blue , a nonprofit that strives to enrich the lives of America’s veterans by connecting them to their communities through physical and social activity, presented the Old Glory Relay for the third consecutive year. Starbucks and the Schultz Family Foundation are among the event’s supporters and a number of Starbucks partners (employees) participated in the relay. 
“Starbucks is proud to partner with Team Red, White & Blue to bring veterans, their families and American citizens together to support the Old Glory Relay,” said Virginia Bergin,   Impact. “Running and cycling under the American flag for 4,000 miles across the country is a great way for veterans and civilians to come together for a shared purpose. Our Military Family Stores are designed to build a stronger connection between the military and communities and served as an ideal connection point between partners and relay teams to host Hail and Farewells.” 
Melissa Ochs, district manager for the region around Camp Pendleton, was at a Starbucks Military Family Store in Oceanside, California, late in the morning of September 30 when she and two-dozen others waiting to greet the participating athletes heard U.S. Marines chanting as they neared the store with the flag held high. 
“It gave me chills,” Ochs said. “The runner who they gave the flag to was an older gentleman. He was a veteran and he grabbed the flag and was out. The pride that every single person holding that flag or being a part of it demonstrated was heartwarming.” Starbucks Allies with Veterans Service Organizations 
The partnership between Starbucks and Team Red, White & Blue reflects the company’s commitment to creating opportunities for veterans as they transition from military service to civilian careers. Starbucks, which has hired 8,000 veterans and military spouses toward a goal of hiring 10,000 by the end of 2018, also partners with Team Rubicon, which deploys veterans to provide disaster relief; Blue Star Families, which addresses challenges to military families; and The Mission Continues, which empowers veterans adjusting to civilian life through community service.

posts.title: Starbucks BOGO rings in holiday season
posts.text:
Close 1 of 2 
Starbucks holiday drinks are out, and they are gifting them — get a free one when you buy on — during a special BOGO happy hour 2-5 p.m. now through Monday. Joseph Pisani 
Starbucks holiday brews are back, and you can get two for one from 2 to 5 p.m. now through Monday, Nov. 14. Starbucks BOGO rings in holiday season Nov 11, 2016 ( … ) 
Starbucks holiday drinks are out, and they are gifting them — get a free one when you buy on — during a special BOGO happy hour 2-5 p.m. now through Monday. Joseph Pisani 
Starbucks holiday brews are back, and you can get two for one from 2 to 5 p.m. now through Monday, Nov. 14. 
It's officially the holiday season: Starbucks rolled out its tasty seasonal brews — iced and hot drinks alike — last week. 
And they are giving us an early gift wrapped inside a festive red cup: A BOGO — buy a holiday drink and get a second one free, from 2 to 5 p.m. now through Monday, Nov. 14. 
Yeah, we know, the Christmas season doesn't truly begin until Black Friday — day after Thanksgiving, which falls on Nov. 24. But caffeine junkies know better: It's the introduction of the Starbucks red cups, filled with Caramel Brulée Latte, Chestnut Praline Latte, Fudge Hot Chocolate, Eggnog Latte, Gingerbread Latte, Peppermint Mocha, Toffee Nut Latte and Christmas Cookie Latte. thread.title: 3 Reasons Why Starbucks Is A Must Own For All Dividend Growth Investors
thread.title_full: 3 Reasons Why Starbucks Is A Must Own For All Dividend Growth Investors

posts.title: 3 Reasons Why Starbucks Is A Must Own For All Dividend Growth Investors
posts.text: 9.1% Click to enlarge The combination of Starbucks' latest giant payout hike, plus the market's irrational slide this past year has resulted in a fantastic opportunity to get Starbucks at its all time high-yield (note that the below chart hasn't had time to update the yield due to the dividend hike being too new). SBUX Dividend Yield (NYSE: TTM ) data by YCharts Better yet, because long-term total returns are driven by yield + dividend growth , today's investors can buy Starbucks at a price that promises to crush the market's historical 9.1% CAGR since 1871. In fact, given the remarkably cyclical nature of Starbucks' yield, I wouldn't be surprised to see it hit a price of $120 to $125 by the end of 2018; which would represent a 52% CAGR from today's share price. Not that I necessarily recommend anyone partake in this kind of long-term technical analysis mind you, and I'm not saying that Starbucks' yield will always move in such perfect rhythm. However, no matter how you slice it, this blue chip dividend growth champ is well on its way to delivering superior long-term returns for investors. Risks to watch for There are two main risks that I'm watching for going forward. First, the strong 2016 global comps were pretty much all due to increased pricing, with flat or even slightly negative traffic. While this pricing power is indeed impressive, and shows the strength of the loyalty rewards program, at the same time long-term comps growth, and thus dividend growth, will require higher foot traffic over time. Fortunately, improving economic conditions, including rising wages, and stronger consumer retail spending should help to alleviate some of this risk in 2017. Of course, such positive short-term trends can quickly reverse themselves, and if the US were to enter a recession then Starbucks might struggle to post positive comps at all. Even if the best case scenario does play out, in which US economic growth continues to accelerate, raising consumer confidence, and Starbucks' store traffic, a stronger economy would likely result in higher interest rates. That in turn would likely cause further strengthening of the dollar and result in stronger negative currency headwinds just as Starbucks is doubling down on its store growth abroad. We've already seen long-term treasury yields rise by about 50 basis points since the shocking results of the election. And that's just on the market's rising inflationary expectations from the Trump administration's potential fiscal stimulus plan (infrastructure spending + tax cuts). Click to enlarge Source: CME Group Add in the near certainty that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term rates in December, and that Janet Yellen's replacement in February of 2018 is likely to be more hawkish, and a rising dollar might end up as one of Starbucks' biggest growth headwinds in the coming years. Bottom line: If you are a dividend growth investor and you don't own Starbucks you're doing it wrong I'm not going to lie to you and say that this is the bottom for Starbucks, or that the last year's underperformance guarantees market thumping returns in 2017 or even 2018. In the short-term the market can be crazy, and totally unpredictable. BUT what I can tell you is that Starbucks is blessed with visionary management with a solid plan for how to keep the growth, and rising margin train rolling along for many years to come. Which is likely to mean continued dividend growth excellence, and over the long-term, potentially spectacular total returns. Disclosure: I am/we are long SBUX. thread.title: 3 Reasons I'm Building Up A Stash Of Starbucks
thread.title_full: 3 Reasons I'm Building Up A Stash Of Starbucks

posts.title: 3 Reasons I'm Building Up A Stash Of Starbucks
posts.text:
Starbucks is a company that sells an addictive product. 
Starbucks has a growing global footprint. 
Starbucks has a growing dividend payment. As a relatively new investor who's interested in a growing income stream that builds over time, I'm looking for companies that have an opportunity to help me toward that goal. Popular companies that have iconic brands and revenue streams that have the opportunity to grow are some of the best places to start when combined with relatively low dividend payout ratios. One of the companies that has caught my interest over the past year has been Starbucks (NASDAQ: SBUX ). This company, which started in Seattle with a single coffee shop way back in 1971 has seen quite a bit of exponential growth over nearly a half-century in existence. A Massive Growth Story When Starbucks went public in 1992, it had 165 stores in operation. From this relatively small start, the coffee giant has grown to more than 22,500 stores at the end of 2015, which included an increase of more than 1,100 stores in the past year (Source: Starbucks Company Timeline ). In 2014, the company had a goal of having 30,000 stores in operation within five years. This is some pretty substantial growth in a short amount of time. The company's main product is coffee, which is a relatively addictive product. I know people who come to work with a cup of Starbucks coffee on a regular basis. There is no doubt that the product is pretty popular. Additionally, it sells at a premium to the coffee that many other companies sell, which tends to lead to higher profitability. This addictive product is the first reason that I'm investing in SBUX. The second reason is the growing international footprint that the company has. I have been to several different countries throughout the world in the past decade or so. In every major city that I've visited in the time, I've seen at least one, and usually multiple Starbucks. This goes from Prague, to Paris, to Tegucigalpa. Much of the growth that the company has experienced has been overseas. This provides geographical diversification through a single American-based stock, as revenue is coming from many different areas of the world. Included in this growth is an intended 1,400 new stores in China that should be opened between 2016 and 2019. The Chinese economy has been growing rapidly in recent years, and there is hope that new additions to the middle class in China and other developing nations will spend their money on the addictive nectar. Growing Revenue and a Growing Dividend My final reason for investing in Starbucks is the rapidly growing dividend payment. Over the past five years, going back to FY2012, the revenue that Starbucks has been able to bring in has gone up every year. Revenue has grown from $13.3 billion in FY2012 to $21.32 billion in the most recent fiscal year. This is a CAGR of slightly more than 12 percent, which most people will be pretty happy with should it continue over the long term. Additionally, net income has more than doubled over the same 5-year period from $1.38 billion to $2.82 billion. This is a CAGR of more than 19 percent between 2012 and 2016. It should be noted that net income in 2013 was only $8.8 million, but all of the other years in the sample were very profitable. (Source: MarketWatch ) While this revenue and income growth alone would be a great reason to invest in SBUX, there is also the issue of the dividend. As a dividend investor who likes to see the dividend grow over time, Starbucks has not failed to impress on this front, either. The coffee giant paid its first dividend a little more than six years ago in March 2010, and the first payment was $0.05 on a split-adjusted basis. From this small start, in which an investor who owned 100 shares at the time would have earned a mere $10, SBUX recently raised its dividend to $0.25 per share, a 25 percent increase on a year-over-year basis. This increase, if continued, would result in a doubling of the dividend in slightly less than three years. The investor who would have held 100 shares and earned $10 back in March 2010 would now own 200 shares after the 2-for-1 split that took place in April 2015 and receive a dividend payment of $50 each quarter. The dividend has grown five-fold since its inception. Even after all of this dividend growth in just over six years, the dividend payout ratio on a trailing 12-month basis is at 56 percent. This will likely change when the annual report is released. The current yield is 1.83 percent. Both of these metrics are higher than they have been previously, but should revenue and income continue to grow, there is no reason to believe that Starbucks will not be able to grow the dividend into the future as well, albeit at a slower rate than it has grown in the past six years. This is the main reason that I'm nibbling at SBUX and planning to build up a position over time. Disclosure: I am/we are long SBUX. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. As losses up to and including all capital invested can occur, be sure to do due diligence and check with a financial professional before investing in securities. thread.title: Starbucks: Challenges Ahead
thread.title_full: Starbucks: Challenges Ahead

posts.title: Starbucks: Challenges Ahead
posts.text:
We are concerned that rising coffee prices could impact margins over the next 12 months. 
Furthermore, the strong U.S. dollar and weakening yuan could impact its earnings growth next year. 
With its stock trading at 28.5 times earnings, any sign of slowing growth could cause a sell off. 
We believe investors should stay clear of the coffee giant until at least its first quarter results. Click to enlarge Global coffee giant Starbucks (NASDAQ: SBUX ) is easily one of our favorite companies to own and when the price is right you'll almost certainly find it in our portfolio. Although its stock is down 9% this year and looks to be much better value than in recent times, there are a number of challenges ahead that could mean it's better for investors to hold off making an investment. Click to enlarge Sourced from Finviz The first challenge will be rising coffee prices. Despite the fact that coffee prices have fallen since the election due to a strengthening U.S. dollar, we don't see prices falling much lower. As demand continues to grow at a quicker rate than supply, we expect this deficit to keep prices higher for longer. Earlier this year the USDA predicted that demand for coffee would reach its highest levels ever in the United States, China, India, and Japan this year Unfortunately for coffee buyers though the supply just isn't there to cope with this demand. This has led to coffee stockpiles falling for eleven straight quarters. According to Bloomberg this is the longest run of declines since records began in 1995. As a result the USDA has forecast for global coffee inventories to drop to a four-year low this time next year. This is not good news for Starbucks, Dunkin Donuts (NASDAQ: DNKN ), and UK-based Costa Coffee operator Whitbread ( OTC:WTBCF ). All three are likely to see margins negatively impacted by rising prices. As you can see above, prior to inventories sinking to extreme low levels four years ago, coffee prices rose strongly. When you factor in the incredible rise in demand since then, it does make you wonder how far prices could rise this time around. This makes going long with the iPath Dow Jones-UBS Coffee ETN (NYSEARCA: JO ) a very tempting proposition in our view. Although these companies will of course hedge in order to avoid rising prices. There's only so long you can hedge prices before they impact you. With no sign of the coffee deficit coming to an end next year and demand expected to rise, Starbucks and its peers may have to adjust to life with higher coffee prices. As we have previously pointed out, in fiscal year 2012 Starbucks noted how the high coffee prices were negatively impacting its performance in its 10K . The company explained that: 
"… the impact of higher commodity costs, mostly coffee, which negatively impacted operating income by approximately $214 million for the year, equivalent to approximately 160 basis points of impact on operating margin." The next concern we have is the strong U.S. dollar (NYSEARCA: UUP ) and the effect this will have on its international earnings. Since Trump won the race to the White House the U.S. dollar index has surged higher. Although it has given back a bit recently, we don't see it dropping much further moving forward. Especially with a rate rise in December looking almost inevitable now. Whilst the Americas segment is still the number one contributor to revenue, with its U.S. stores providing the bulk of the sales, in the fourth quarter Starbucks pulled in almost 31% of its revenue from international markets. The big worry in our opinion is China's decision to devalue the yuan. As you can see below the U.S. dollar has appreciated in value against the yuan considerably in the last few months. Scarily the chart above is out of date as well, with China letting its currency weaken to an eight-year low of 6.87 overnight. That's an almost 8 percent decline in value in the space of 12 months for the yuan. With Starbucks pinning a great deal of its growth on the China market, we fear the significant FX headwinds it will face next year are going to result in lower-than-expected earnings growth. At present analysts expect earnings to grow 15.6 percent on last year's result (excluding the 53rd week) to $2.14 per share. But we're not sure it will deliver on this. So with its stock trading on a price to earnings ratio of 28.5, we do feel it is at risk of further declines over the next couple of quarters if its earnings growth is lacking. Because of this we think it would be prudent for investors to stay clear of Starbucks until at least its first quarter result. By then we should be able to see if coffee prices and the strong dollar are impacting its performance. If Starbucks escapes unscathed then we see it being fair value right now. But if it doesn't, a rerating down to a price to earnings ratio of 20 to 25 might be appropriate. Until then, best of luck with your investments! posts.text:
Google 
Starbucks is giving a sneak preview of the 13 new designs set to adorn their red holiday cups, starting Thursday. 
The designs include Christmas lights, candy canes, snowflakes and a reindeer, to name a few. Starbucks chose the winning designs from an Instagram contest that included submissions from more than a dozen countries. 
“We hope that this year’s red holiday cup designs express the shared spirit of the holidays as told by our customers,” said Sharon Rothstein, Starbucks global chief marketing officer. 
It’s been a year since Starbucks rolled out solid red holiday cups with a minimalist logo, unwittingly sparking a backlash on Twitter as people accusing the Seattle company of waging a “war on Christmas.” It's September, when does the War on Christmas start? Get ready @Starbucks pic.twitter.com/8Id9YW5kAl 
— (((tramosUSA))) (@voteblue16) September 7, 2016 
Led by “American evangelist” Joshua Feuerstein, some customers told baristas their names were “Merry Christmas” so they could tweet photos of the cups with the holiday message written on them. 
Starbucks is sweetening the rollout of the new holiday cups in 2016 by offering a free drink of equal or lesser value between November 10-14, from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. See the full rules here .

thread.section_title: Starbucks, Gap, Nike and Others Demand Trump to Stand By Climate Deal – FOX40
thread.title: Starbucks, Gap, Nike and Others Demand Trump to Stand By Climate Deal
thread.title_full: Starbucks, Gap, Nike and Others Demand Trump to Stand By Climate Deal

posts.author: Anisca Miles
posts.title: Starbucks, Gap, Nike and Others Demand Trump to Stand By Climate Deal
posts.text:
NEW YORK (CNNMoney) — If President-elect Donald Trump is going to go soft on climate change regulations, big business is going to put up a big stink.
In an open letter on Wednesday, Starbucks, Gap, Nike, L’Oreal, and hundreds of other American businesses joined together to tell Trump that they are committed to fighting global warming. And they implored the future president — who has called climate change a hoax —to keep the current low-carbon policies championed by President Obama.
“We want the US economy to be energy efficient and powered by low-carbon energy,” they wrote, adding “failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk.”
More than 300 businesses signed the letter. It was announced in a press conference during the 22nd session of the Conference of the Parties (COP 22) currently being held in Morocco.
Trump said during his campaign that he would pull the U.S. out of the historic Paris Climate Agreement. The 175 signatories to the non-binding treaty, including the United States, are committed to reducing the emission of greenhouse gases as a way of fighting climate change.
Business leaders are not the only ones concerned over Trump’s climate change stance. Scientists have questioned what a refusal of the Paris Agreement would mean for the environment, and have expressed concern over Trump’s signaling that he will place climate change deniers in top White House positions.

posts.author: Business Wire
posts.title: Starbucks to Host 2016 Investor Day
posts.text:
November 16, 2016 5:39pm Comments Share: SEATTLE--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- 
Starbucks Corporation (NASDAQ: SBUX ) will host its 2016 Investor Day on Wednesday, December 7th. The event will feature presentations and a Q&A session with Howard Schultz, chairman and chief executive officer; Kevin Johnson, president and chief operating officer; Scott Maw, executive vice president and chief financial officer; and other members of the company's senior leadership team. 
Due to limited capacity, attendance is by invitation only. The event will be webcast live and all interested parties are invited to access the webcast from the company's website: http://investor.starbucks.com . The event is scheduled to begin at 8:00 a.m. ET and will continue until approximately 12 noon ET. Following a break for lunch, the webcast of the live event will resume at approximately 1:30 p.m. ET and is expected to conclude at approximately 3:00 p.m. ET. 
The presentation slides shown at the event and on the live webcast will be available for download on the company's website by the end of the day on December 7, 2016. A replay of the webcast will remain accessible through January 6, 2017. 
About Starbucks 
Since 1971, Starbucks Coffee Company has been committed to ethically sourcing and roasting high-quality arabica coffee. Today, with stores around the globe, the company is the premier roaster and retailer of specialty coffee in the world. Through our unwavering commitment to excellence and our guiding principles, we bring the unique Starbucks Experience to life for every customer through every cup. To share in the experience, please visit us in our stores or online at news.starbucks.com or www.starbucks.com .

thread.title: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change | Mic
thread.title_full: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change | Mic

posts.title: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change | Mic
posts.text:
TWEET Starbucks , Nike and more than 360 other businesses and investors have called on President-elect Donald Trump and other world leaders to remain committed to the Paris agreement on climate change. "Failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk. But the right action now will create jobs and boost U.S. competitiveness," the group said in a statement released and presented at United Nations climate talks in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Wednesday . Other signers include conglomerate Unilever, chemicals giant Dupont, and technology company Hewlett Packard. The Paris treaty was signed by nearly 200 countries to try and restore greenhouse gas emissions to sustainable levels by the year 2100 . A major goal is to limit the rise in average global temperatures to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit. A number of the world's largest companies are urging President-elect Trump to remain in the Paris Agreement. Source: Mark Lennihan/AP Backers of climate change action are concerned because there's good reason to expect that the United States might try and walk back its efforts to limit emissions in Trump's administration. The president-elect has called climate change a " hoax ," promised to dismantle the Environmental Protection Agency , and appointed Myron Ebell — who has argued greenhouse gas emissions could actually be beneficial — to lead his EPA transition effort. Even Exxon Mobile, the oil and gas multinational that has had a fraught relationship with climate change activists in the past, backs the Paris agreement. Suzanne McCarron, Exxon's vice president of public and government affairs, tweeted about the company's ongoing support of the treaty on Nov. 10, the morning after the election. 
The Paris agreement is an important step forward by governments in addressing the serious risks of #ClimateChange https://t.co/X7JubyyArv Of course, other countries in the agreement may fight back in the event that the U.S. tries to back out. Former French President Nicholas Sarkozy — who will also likely be his center-right party's nominee for President — has floated the idea of imposing a tariff on U.S. imports to make up for reneging on the Paris agreement's financial commitments. That would need to be approved by other countries in the EU for it to have the desired effect, although it would pack a punch — Europe is still the United States' biggest trading partner. The clock is ticking: September 2016 was the hottest September in 136 years , as long as records have been kept. Like us on Facebook:

posts.title: Cramer says 'lurking buyers' propped up stocks like Disney, NVIDIA and Starbucks
posts.text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Nov 17, 2016, 01:10 GMT - UK Markets open in 6 hrs 50 mins Cramer says 'lurking buyers' propped up stocks like Disney, NVIDIA and Starbucks By Abigail Stevenson | CNBC – 1 hour 55 minutes ago 99.12 +1.42 Jim Cramer diagnosed the stock market with a case of the "wacky bids underneath" on Wednesday. 
A bid underneath is a technical term used by money managers, which means that as a stock sinks, buyers are on the sidelines and ready to do some buying. Often an institutional trader will ask for a "picture" to figure out what the actual supply and demand balance is before buying a stock. 
"Ever since the Trump rally began, there have been buyers lurking underneath. They remain, even when the S&P 500 futures might drive stocks down off of whatever ails the market on any given day. They prop up the stocks that they are lurking under," the " Mad Money " host said. 
However, once the patience wears off, the buyers step up and end up competing with one another and the price of the stock rises. Cramer attributed the lurking buyers underneath propelled stocks like Disney , Starbucks and NVIDIA on Wednesday. 
Just a week ago, Disney shares fell amid concerns that ESPN is losing subscribers. However, Cramer noted that on the conference call, CEO Bob Iger said he was feeling more bullish about ESPN lately, which was an encouraging sign. 
Sure enough, Deutsche Bank upgraded Disney to a buy from a hold on Wednesday because of those encouraging signs. This prompted buyers to step up. 
Even when the market turned down, the buyers underneath continued to buy stock. 
"The opportunity was just too great, and they didn't want to miss it," Cramer said. 
Likewise, two weeks ago there was lukewarm praise for the quarter Starbucks reported. After an initial rally, the stock retreated down near where it was when rumors surfaced that it could report a weak quarter. 
Starbucks rose to $55 a share on Wednesday. Momentum is now with the bulls, and buyers lurking are now willing to pay up for the stock on a down tape, according to Cramer's colleague at Real Money, Bruce Kamich. Whatever investors disliked about Starbucks is now less relevant than all of the good things that are going on, especially in China, Cramer said. 
On Tuesday, Cramer highlighted NVIDIA as the "new Intel of this generation." Even after the stock's 30 percent gain in the past month, lurking buyers surfaced and took it up another 6 percent on Wednesday. 
"Buyers just can't wait for this market to come down. They are stepping up each day for a host of stocks. The result? I always say there is a bull market somewhere and right now there are almost too many to count," Cramer said.

thread.title: Gas station, Starbucks planned for Gateway project in Temecula
thread.title_full: Gas station, Starbucks planned for Gateway project in Temecula

posts.author: AARON CLAVERIE
posts.title: Gas station, Starbucks planned for Gateway project in Temecula
posts.text:
By AARON CLAVERIE   Updated: 5:51 p.m. Gas station, Starbucks planned for Gateway project in Temecula Related article » 
There's a new "gateway" to the city of Temecula. 
The City Council this week approved the "Gateway to Temecula" project, a shopping center that will feature a Starbucks, gas station and an LA Fitness location. 
The center is slated for land at the northwest corner of La Paz Road and Temecula Parkway, a long vacant parcel that a couple of years ago was being fitted for a new hotel and an upscale restaurant . 
If the hotel/restaurant plans were ever a serious possibility, they appear to have been jettisoned some time ago. 
According to the designer of the project, Irvine-based Creative Development & Management, Inc. , the team worked with a nearby homeowners association for "several years" to craft a "lifestyle center" that "enhances the quality of life for Temecula residents." 
"From the color of the paint to the types of water-wise plants to the dark skies lighting fixtures, the 'Gateway to Temecula' has been painstakingly designed. Its architecture, signage, and way the businesses operate, all fit together with the Los Ranchitos Community," CDM posted on its website. 
During the meeting, there was a long discussion about a proposed upgrade to the intersection at La Paz and Ynez road, which is served right now by an overworked stop sign. 
To deal with the traffic the center is expected to generate, the city imposed conditions on the developer to either pay their fair share toward building a roundabout at that intersection or contribute to a traffic signal there before tenants will be allowed to set up shop. 
The council, which eventually OK'd the project in a 5-0 vote, was convinced by both staff and the applicant that the conditions were sufficient to address a host of contingencies that included the possibility of the developer being unable to secure right-of-way to build the roundabout. 
In that scenario, the developer would work to install a traffic light as a sort of Plan B. 
With the vote, the council signed off on a zone change from professional office to community commercial for the project, which features around 61,000 square feet of commercial space on an 8.79 acre site. 
At the corner there will be signage that denotes the project's "gateway" status, which will take the form of words to that effect next to the sign the gas station will use to display prices.

SEATTLE --(BUSINESS WIRE) Starbucks Corporation (NASDAQ: SBUX) will host its 2016 Investor Day on Wednesday, December 7th. The event will feature presentations and a Q&A session with Howard Schultz, chairman and chief executive officer; Kevin Johnson, president and chief operating officer; Scott Maw, executive vice president and chief financial officer; and other members of the company’s senior leadership team.
Due to limited capacity, attendance is by invitation only. The event will be webcast live and all interested parties are invited to access the webcast from the company’s website: http://investor.starbucks.com . The event is scheduled to begin at 8:00 a.m. ET and will continue until approximately 12 noon ET. Following a break for lunch, the webcast of the live event will resume at approximately 1:30 p.m. ET and is expected to conclude at approximately 3:00 p.m. ET.
The presentation slides shown at the event and on the live webcast will be available for download on the company’s website by the end of the day on December 7, 2016. A replay of the webcast will remain accessible through January 6, 2017.

Starbucks: Earn free espresso after 5 holiday beverage purchases POSTED BY Living on the Cheap 
Starbucks is helping make the holidays a little merrier with a FREE Grande handcrafted espresso beverage (16-ounce) of your choice, after you purchase five holiday beverages. Choose from Chestnut Praline Latte, Peppermint Mocha and Skinny Peppermint Mocha, Caramel Brulée Latte, Gingerbread Latte, Eggnog Latte, Teavana Joy Brewed Tea and Spiced Sweet Cream Nariño 70 Cold Brew. (The offer applies to hot, iced and blended holiday beverages.) 
Here’s how it works: At participating cafés, pick up a holiday beverage tasting card at the register (or ask a friendly barista for one) — while supplies last. Then, collect a sticker each time you purchase a holiday beverage (at full price) from Nov. 15 through Dec. 25 . Once you’ve collected five stickers, redeem your completed card for a FREE Grande handcrafted espresso beverage of your choice. Completed free beverage cards expire January 31, 2017. Price and participation may vary.

thread.title: Corporations looking ahead to post-Trump landscape
thread.title_full: Corporations looking ahead to post-Trump landscape

posts.author: The Washington Post
posts.title: Corporations looking ahead to post-Trump landscape
posts.text:
Read Article 
Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz may have spoken for many corporate CEOs when he said in a memo to employees that he was “stunned” about the election outcome last week. 
But a week later, as the news of Trump’s win gave way to planning for his transition, the reality appears to be taking hold, and corporations are navigating how to respond in the aftermath of a historic election that proved explosively divisive. On the campaign trail, Trump bashed several U.S. companies. Rhetoric about women and minorities from Trump’s campaign, his supporters or his past create a minefield for corporations that tout their diversity and inclusion policies. Some CEOs or corporate officials who have spoken out have seen calls for boycotts of their brands on social media. 
“They’re clearly not as vocal, and in many cases are laying low and waiting to see what really is generated through the Republican-controlled Congress,” says Thomas Cooke, a professor at Georgetown University’s McDonough School of Business. 
HOPING FOR TAX REFORM 
Yet that Republican-controlled Congress is also expected to usher in pro-business changes such as tax reform, infrastructure plans and regulatory changes that have some in the business community excited, said John Engler, a former governor of Michigan and the president of the Business Roundtable, which represents CEOs of the largest public corporations. 
“The reaction from the election has simply been ‘let’s get ready to take advantage of this opportunity that’s presented itself,'” he said in an interview. CEOs, he says, “are interested in growth. They awakened a week ago and said ‘wow, what was not possible is possible.’” 
In its aftermath, the chief response from CEOs speaking out about the election included congratulations, calls for unity and commitments to diversity. J.P. Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon wrote to his employees “we have just been through one of the most contentious elections in memory, which can make it even harder to put our differences aside.” Apple’s Tim Cook quoted Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and reminded employees that “our company is open to all … regardless of what they look like, where they come from, how they worship or who they love.” 
TRADE DEALS AT STAKE 
Some CEOs are starting to publicly offer more policy-oriented remarks or advice for Trump as the focus shifts from the results of the campaign to how he will govern. On Tuesday, General Electric’s Jeff Immelt, who had written an initial blog post to employees last week, suggested in a CNBC interview that Trump might actually find himself benefiting from trade deals. “I think what the president will learn,” the GE CEO said, “is that as he travels the world, trade deals give him power. … If the president of the United States travels around the world and has nothing to offer from a standpoint of economic connection, you lose half of your negotiating power. This guy is a negotiator, he’s a dealmaker. So I think let’s just wait and see what he does.” 
In a letter to Trump released Tuesday, IBM CEO Ginni Rometty had a few proposals of her own. “I am writing to offer ideas that I believe will help achieve the aspiration you articulated and that can advance a national agenda in a time of profound change,” Rometty wrote. She suggested working together to scale up vocational “new collar” IT jobs, voiced support for a more competitive tax system, and recommended infrastructure projects incorporating technology and artificial intelligence. Share

thread.title_full: Celebrate Christmas holidays with Starbucks festive specials - The Financial Express.

posts.author: FE Online
posts.title: Celebrate Christmas holidays with Starbucks festive specials
posts.text:
Starbucks holiday cups will be served in the more than 25,000 Starbucks stores in 75 countries around the world To mark the arrival of Christmas, Starbucks has introduced festival-based Starbucks Holiday Cups – special red cups that reflect Christmas. Started in 1997, the initiative over the years has seen designs ranging from the modern, using whimsical brushstrokes in bold colors, to the nostalgic, featuring mistletoe and ornaments.
For this Christmas, Starbucks has further introduced new designs. Last year, Starbucks invited customers from around the world to use the red cups as a canvas and share their designs on Instagram. From the entries received, Starbucks picked 13 customers from Illinois to Indonesia, Pennsylvania to Korea, Dubai to Ontario, who created unique pieces of art that reflect what the holiday season means to them. From traditional Christmas lights and ornaments, to snowflakes and winter landscapes, the red cups are inspired by the holiday stories of customers from around the world. A total of 12 designs will appear on hot cups, and there is one design on cold cups.
Starbucks holiday cups will be served in the more than 25,000 Starbucks stores in 75 countries around the world.
“Christmas is a very special time for us at Starbucks and we are delighted to welcome the holiday spirit into our stores. We look forward to expressing the shared spirit of the holidays through our much-awaited Christmas beverages now available in the new red holiday cups,” said Manmeet Vohra, director – marketing and category, TATA Starbucks.
Some of the designs for this year’s collection includes Birds & Flowers by Florencia, Bandung, Indonesia; Holiday Lights by Maria Lauren, New York City; Candy Canes by Jennifer, Seattle, USA; Birch Forest by Chloe, Plainfield, Illinois, USA; Ornaments by Anz Soza, Dubai; Poinsettia by Christina, Bakersfield, California; Graphic Swirls by Erica: Markham, Ontario, Canada; Snowflake Sweater by Alisa, St Petersburg, Russia; Evergreen Forest by Bronwyn, Moscow, Idaho, USA; and Sleigh Ride by Eun Joo, Daejeon, South Korea.

thread.title: Starbucks is Selling a Giant 128-oz Coffee Mug for Christmas
thread.title_full: Starbucks is Selling a Giant 128-oz Coffee Mug for Christmas

posts.author: Q (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Starbucks is Selling a Giant 128-oz Coffee Mug for Christmas
posts.text:
Starbucks looks to go after the "bigger is better" crowd this holiday season with the 138-oz Giant Classic Mug as a potential Christmas gift for the Starbucks fan in your life.

While the picture doesn't really give you a sense of the scale of the cup, it measures 9.84" H x 12" W (with handle) and carries a hefty price tag of $94.95.

At 138 ounces, the mug is big enough to fill up with a little over eight Grandes (their 16-oz cup size). Interestingly, it isn't biggest cup Starbucks has ever offered. Last year, they offered the the Big Logo Mug measuring 14.57" H x 15.75" W (with handle) over in Japan (pictured below). Also, apparently, back in 2001, for their 30th anniversary, they put out 1,000 5-gallon (640 oz) mugs for promotional display.

Unfortunately, for those hoping to drink 128 ounces of coffee from the mug in one sitting, it's labeled as being "for decorated purposes only," which means it is probably not coated inside to hold liquids. While you might chance a drink or two, I wouldn't use it for a regular cup (although I suppose you can glaze/seal it yourself...). Also, the Giant Classic Mug is already sold out online , although there's always they chance that they'll restock as Christmas approaches.

Photos via Starbucks & Starbucks Japan, respectively. Read more at Brand Eating !

thread.section_title: Nike, Starbucks, and Gap Urge Trump to Stay in the Paris Climate Deal – Fortune
thread.title: Nike, Starbucks, and Gap Urge Trump to Stay in the Paris Climate Deal
thread.title_full: Nike, Starbucks, and Gap Urge Trump to Stay in the Paris Climate Deal

posts.author: Reuters
posts.title: Nike, Starbucks, and Gap Urge Trump to Stay in the Paris Climate Deal
posts.text:
More than 360 businesses and investors called on U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and world leaders on Wednesday to continue to support agreed curbs on global warming and to speed up efforts to move to a low-carbon economy.
In a statement addressed to Trump , U.S. President Barack Obama, members of the U.S. Congress and global leaders, the group, called 360+, reaffirmed its commitment to the Paris Agreement on climate change.
The 360+ group includes companies such as DuPont dd , Gap gps , General Mills @general gis , Hewlett Packard hpq , Hilton hlt , Kellogg k , Levi Strauss & Co., L’Oreal USA, Nike nke , Mars Incorporated mars , Schneider Electric sbgsy , Starbucks and Unilever ul .
The Paris Agreement, aiming to phase out net greenhouse gas emissions this century, came into force on Nov. 4 and now has backing from 110 nations including the United States.
The Nov. 7-18 meeting in Marrakesh is where U.N. officials and government representatives are trying to work out the details of the pact. However, Trump ‘s victory in the U.S. election last week has overshadowed the event.
Trump has threatened to tear up the U.S. commitment to the accord.
The 360+ group called on U.S. leaders to continue to participate in the Paris Agreement, support the continuation of U.S. commitments on climate change and continue to invest in low-carbon solutions at home and abroad.
“Failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk. But the right action now will create jobs and boost U.S. competitiveness,” the group said, in the statement presented at U.N. climate talks being held this week in Marrakesh, Morocco.
“Implementing the Paris Climate Agreement will enable and encourage businesses and investors to turn the billions of dollars in existing low-carbon investments into the trillions of dollars the world needs to bring clean energy prosperity to all,” the group added.

thread.title: Simple Trump story
thread.title_full: Simple Trump story

posts.title: Simple Trump story
posts.text: Top Next Comment I was getting some hot chocolate from Starbucks a few days ago and while I was waiting for it by the counter, this group of younger teenagers came up to get their drinks as well. So I'm just standing there, and when one of the girls in the group gets her drink, she looks over to me and says "Hey, **** Trump! Haha yeah!" I don't miss a beat and say "Okay then, get a room". She walks away telling her group "I did not expect that, that is not how I expected that to go." That's all really, just thought it was funny. Thought back on it and it mighta been better if I'd said "Well it's about $170 for a night at the Marriott in downtown, but I doubt you're his type..." Se la vie.

thread.title: ‘I voted for Trump!’: White customer demands special privileges in Starbucks meltdown
thread.title_full: ‘I voted for Trump!’: White customer demands special privileges in Starbucks meltdown

posts.author: Travis Gettys
posts.title: ‘I voted for Trump!’: White customer demands special privileges in Starbucks meltdown
posts.text:
Trump voter flies into a rage at Starbucks (Twitter) Don't miss stories. Follow Raw Story! Follow @rawstory 
A Donald Trump flew into a racist tantrum when his Starbucks order took longer than he believed it should have. 
The man was caught on video hurling insults at employees and customers at a coffee shop near the University of Miami campus, reported the Miami New-Times . 
He started hurling Trump’s name at black employees, who he accused of “anti-white discrimination” because his coffee was delayed, witnesses said. 
Related: Trump-loving coffee shop owner insists he is not racist after threatening to hang black ‘monkeys’ 
Another customer called the man an “assh*le,” and he replied “f*ck you, b*tch”— and that’s when Jorge de Cárdenas began recording. 
His video captured the man, who has not been identified, calling a black employee “trash” and demanding a refund. 
“I voted for Trump! Trump!” the man said. “You lost, now give me my money back.” 
The man demands the black employee’s name and continues insulting her, and another customer asks him to be more respectful or leave. 
The Trump supporter then turns his fury on the other customer, and he threatened to punch the other man before storming out of the coffee shop. 
Cárdenas said he didn’t understand why the Trump supporter was so angry. 
“The funny thing, besides just the concept of ‘anti-white discrimination,’ is just yelling ‘Trump!’ for no reason,” Cárdenas said. “Like dude, you won.” #trump supporter in #miami @Starbucks attacks & threatens patrons & staff bc coffee took too long, blames anti-white "discrimination" pic.twitter.com/HRj9EahrMy 
— jorge de cárdenas (@Jbdcl) November 16, 2016 About the Author

thread.title: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change
thread.title_full: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change | Mic

posts.author: mic.com
posts.title: Starbucks, Nike, and hundreds of other companies beg Donald Trump to fight climate change
posts.text:
Starbucks , Nike and more than 360 other businesses and investors have called on President-elect Donald Trump and other world leaders to remain committed to the Paris agreement on climate change.
"Failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk. But the right action now will create jobs and boost U.S. competitiveness," the group said in a statement released and presented at United Nations climate talks in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Wednesday .
Other signers include conglomerate Unilever, chemicals giant Dupont, and technology company Hewlett Packard.
The Paris treaty was signed by nearly 200 countries to try and restore greenhouse gas emissions to sustainable levels by the year 2100 . A major goal is to limit the rise in average global temperatures to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit.
A number of the world's largest companies are urging President-elect Trump to remain in the Paris Agreement. Source: Mark Lennihan/AP Backers of climate change action are concerned because there's good reason to expect that the United States might try and walk back its efforts to limit emissions in Trump's administration.
The president-elect has called climate change a " hoax ," promised to dismantle the Environmental Protection Agency , and appointed Myron Ebell — who has argued greenhouse gas emissions could actually be beneficial — to lead his EPA transition effort.
Even Exxon Mobile, the oil and gas multinational that has had a fraught relationship with climate change activists in the past, backs the Paris agreement.
Suzanne McCarron, Exxon's vice president of public and government affairs, tweeted about the company's ongoing support of the treaty on Nov. 10, the morning after the election.
The Paris agreement is an important step forward by governments in addressing the serious risks of #ClimateChange https://t.co/X7JubyyArv
Of course, other countries in the agreement may fight back in the event that the U.S. tries to back out.
Former French President Nicholas Sarkozy — who will also likely be his center-right party's nominee for President — has floated the idea of imposing a tariff on U.S. imports to make up for reneging on the Paris agreement's financial commitments.
That would need to be approved by other countries in the EU for it to have the desired effect, although it would pack a punch — Europe is still the United States' biggest trading partner.
The clock is ticking: September 2016 was the hottest September in 136 years , as long as records have been kept.
